Before I get migraine something similar happens to these optical illusions. I get a big blind spot that my brain tries to fill in, but by doing so it makes things invisible by blending them into the background. Reading becomes almost impossible for example because only one letter can appear at one time, often only when they are in my peripheral vision, and when I try to look at them straight they disappear. It's somewhat similar to the dot you get from having looked straight in to the sun for too long but weirder and seemlessly camouflaged into your vision.

For all of you that are saying that you can see the dot, either you are doing it wrong or you are blind. Anyone with vision has a blind spot as there is a point on the retina which has the optic nerve(The nerve which carries signals from your eye to the brain).
As the opening has no cones or rods, you can't see from that point hence the name 'blind' spot.
To make the trick work, you have to either close your left eye and stare the cross with your right eye, or close your right eye and stare the dot with your left eye. Then after that move your head back and forth from the monitor until the dot or cross disappears, or if it is a mobile screen then you can move your phone towards or away from you till the dot or cross disappears.

To the people who can't find their blind spot, maybe this will help.
It took me way longer to find it than I want to admit. If you are like me then It won't work on full screen, and it won't work having the laptop in your lap looking upwards or downwards at the screen, you have to be at the same level looking directly at it. If you wear glasses it does help taking them off, but it isn't necessary when you get it. Now close the left eye and stare at the cross, try not to blink while you slowly move the screen further and further away or closer depending on how you sit. Remember don't blink, if you blink at the wrong moment you might miss it and go past the spot. Repeat until you find it and good luck :)

This isn't exactly true. A lot of this is based off of how your brain works, that is how much of both hemispheres you use. Depending on which side you use more you will see things move differently than someone who uses the other hemisphere more. And if you are like me who uses both side equally or can switch between them you see things VERY differently. Most people see the 'spinning dancer' spin in one direction but I can make her spin both ways sometimes very quickly. Just like the color changing shapes in this video, I don't see them as he describes but slightly differently. Very informative video. You haven't exactly touched base on why there's a blind spot and how to fix it. The blind spot exists because of your eyes' shape. It's not exactly as round as people presume, it has very subtle yet very effective bumps and curves that alter our vision. When you can't see the dot, there's a bump beside the iris where it reflects your line of site and instead mirrors what's surrounding it (white). Because of the excursiveness of these bumps, our brain has learned not to completely trust them and auto fill information even if it's not true. You can fix it by shaving off these bumps very carefully with an X-ACTO knife.

If you have any questions, feel free to leave a reply. I'll get back to you ASAP.

On the vanishing halo:  It may have something to do with receptors in the eye that are specially evolved to detect edges.  The halo doesn't have a distinct edge, even with the built-in tendency of the eyes to involuntarily move a little, so the brain will disregard the fuzzy boundary.  Maybe the movements of the eye are there for the very purpose of helping the eyes detect edges.  This might be how the illusion relates to the idea of unimportance.

7. YES. The flashing seemed to decrease when the dots were moving.
8. NO. The halo steadily persists.
